sen.j: 円仁（えんにん、延暦13年（794年） - 貞観 (日本)6年1月14日 (旧暦)（864年2月24日））は、第3代天台座主。
sen.e: Ennin (794-February 24, 864) was the 3rd generation Tendai zatsu.
Ennin (794-February 24, 864) was the 3rd head priest of the Tendai sect.
sen.cmt: generation Tendai zatsu'→'head priest of the Tendai sect'
sen.e: Ennin (794-February 24, 864) was the 3rd head priest of the Tendai Sect.

sen.j: 慈覚大師（じかくだいし）ともいう。
sen.e: He was also called Jikaku daishi.
He was also known as Jikaku Daishi.
He was also known as Jikaku Daishi.

sen.j: わが国最初の大師号である。
sen.e: It was the first Taishi title of our nation (Japan).
He was the first person in Japan to be given the title Taishi, or Great Teacher.
He was the first person in Japan to be given the title Daishi, or Great Teacher.

sen.j: 入唐八家（最澄・空海・常暁・円行・円仁・恵運・円珍・宗叡）の一人。
sen.e: He was one of Nyutohakke (the eight priest who went to China) (Saicho, Kukai, Jogyo, Engyo, Ennin, Eun, Enchin, and Shuei).
He was one of the eight Nyutohakke priests who travelled to China, the others being Saicho, Kukai, Jogyo, Engyo, Eun, Enchin, and Shuei.
He was one of the eight Nyutohakke priests who travelled to China, the others being Saicho, Kukai, Jogyo, Engyo, Eun, Enchin, and Shuei.

sen.j: 生年は794年（延暦13年）、平安時代の始まりと同じ年で、下野国都賀郡壬生町、現在の壬生寺 (栃木県壬生町)の地に豪族壬生氏の子として生まれる。
sen.e: He was born in Mibu-cho, Tsuga-gun (district), Shimotsuke no Kuni (province) as the son of the local ruling Mibu family in the current Mibu-ji Temple (Mibu-machi, Tochigi Prefecture) in 794, the year when the Heian Period began.

The son of the local ruling Mibu family, he was born in 794, the first year of the Heian Period, in Mibu-cho, Tsuga-gun, Shimotsuke no Kuni, where Mibu-ji Temple (Mibu-machi, Tochigi Prefecture) now stands.
sen.cmt: Changed word order'in the current Mibu-ji Temple'→'where Mibu-ji Temple now stands'
sen.e: The son of the local ruling Mibu clan, he was born in 794, the first year of the Heian period, in Mibu town, Tsuga district, Shimotsuke Province, where Mibu-ji Temple (Mibu-machi, Tochigi Prefecture) now stands.
sen.cmt: 下野国都賀郡壬生町→歴史的場所として言及されているため、Mibu town, Tsuga district, Shimotsuke Provinceとし、Mibu clan, Heian periodとしました。

sen.j: 兄からは儒学を勧められるが早くから仏教に心を寄せ、9歳で大慈寺に入って修行を始める。
sen.e: His older brother recommended him to study Confucianism, but he showed an interest in Buddhism from an early age and entered Daiji-ji Temple at 9 to start his training.
His older brother recommended that he study Confucianism, but he showed an interest in Buddhism from an early age and entered Daiji-ji Temple at the age of 9 to start his training.
sen.cmt: him to'→'that he'Added 'at the age of'
sen.e: His older brother recommended that he study Confucianism, but he showed an interest in Buddhism from an early age and entered Daiji-ji Temple at the age of nine to start his training.

sen.j: 大慈寺の師・広智は鑑真の直弟子道忠の弟子であるが、道忠は早くから最澄の理解者であって、多くの弟子を最澄に師事させている。
sen.e: The master of Daiji-ji Temple, Kochi, was the apprentice of Dochu, the direct apprentice of Jianzhem (Ganjin), but Dochu showed an early understanding of Saicho and sent many pupils to study under Saicho.

The master of Daiji-ji Temple, Kochi, was an apprentice of Dochu, who had studied under Jianzhem (Ganjin in Japanese), though Dochu showed an early appreciation of Saicho and sent many pupils to study under Saicho.
sen.cmt: the'→'a''the direct apprentice of'→'who had studied under'Added 'in Japanese''but'→'though''understanding'→'appreciation'
sen.e: The master of Daiji-ji Temple, Kochi, was an apprentice of Dochu, who had studied under Jianzhem (Ganjin in Japanese), though Dochu showed an early appreciation of Saicho and sent many pupils to study under Saicho.

sen.j: 15歳のとき、唐より最澄が帰国して比叡山延暦寺を開いたと聞くとすぐに比叡山に向かい、最澄に師事する。
sen.e: When Saicho returned to Japan from Tang Dynasty and opened Enryaku-ji Temple on Mount Hiei when he was 15 years old, he immediately went to Mount Hiei to study under Saicho.

When Ennin was 15 years old, after hearing that Saicho had returned to Japan from Tang Dynasty China and founded Enryaku-ji Temple on Mount Hiei, he immediately went to Mount Hiei to study under Saicho.
sen.cmt: Rewrote sentence - Ennin was 15, not Saicho
sen.e: When Ennin was 15 years old, after hearing that Saicho had returned to Japan from Tang Dynasty China and founded Enryaku-ji Temple on Mt. Hiei, he immediately went to Mt. Hiei to study under Saicho.

sen.j: 奈良仏教との反撃と真言密教の興隆という二重の障壁の中で天台宗の確立に立ち向かう師最澄に忠実に仕え、学問と修行に専念して師から深く愛される。
sen.e: He loyally served Saicho, who was trying to establish Tendai between the double walls of the strike back of Nara Buddhism and prosperity of Shingon Esoteric Buddhism and deeply loved Ennin who devoted himself to his study and training.

Through his loyalty and devotion to study and training, Ennin earned the deep affection of Saicho, who was trying to establish the Tendai sect in the face of a resurgence of Nara Buddhism and the prosperity of Shingon Esoteric Buddhism.
sen.cmt: loved'→'affection' ― loved seems a bit stong
sen.e: Through his loyalty and devotion to study and training, Ennin earned the deep affection of Saicho, who was trying to establish the Tendai Sect in the face of a resurgence of Nara Buddhism and the prosperity of Shingon Esoteric Buddhism.

sen.j: 最澄が止観（法華経の注釈書）を学ばせた弟子10人のうち、師の代講を任せられるようになったのは円仁ひとりであった。
sen.e: Ennin was one of ten pupils who learned about shikan (meditation (the annotation of the Hokekyo (Lotus Sutra)) from Saicho, and Ennin was the only disciple who was assigned as the substitute of his master to conduct lectures.

Ennin was one of ten pupils who learned about shikan meditation (using an annotated Lotus Sutra) from Saicho, and Ennin was the only disciple who was assigned to conduct lectures in place of his master.
sen.cmt: Removed 2 sets of brackets.'the annotation of the Hokekyo (Lotus Sutra)'→'using an annotated Lotus Sutra''as the substitute of his master to conduct lectures'→'to conduct lectures in place of his master'
sen.e: Ennin was one of ten pupils who learned about shikan meditation (using an annotated Lotus Sutra) from Saicho, and Ennin was the only disciple who was assigned to conduct lectures in place of his master.

sen.j: 814年（弘仁5年）、言試（国家試験）に合格、翌年得度（出家）する（21歳）。
sen.e: He passed the oral exam (national exam) in 814 and left to become a monk on the following year (21 years old).
He passed the state oral exam in 814 and left to become a monk the following year, when he was 21 years old.
sen.cmt: oral exam (national exam)'→'state oral exam'Deleted 'on''(21 years old)'→'when he was 21 years old'
sen.e: He passed the state oral exam in 814 and left to become a monk the following year, when he was 21 years old.

sen.j: 816年（弘仁7年）、三戒壇の一つ東大寺で具足戒（小乗250戒）を受ける（23歳）。
sen.e: He received gusokukai (Hinayana 250 Lesson) in Todai-ji Temple, one of the Three Kaidan in 816 (23 years old).
In 816, when he was 23 years old, he was ordained, receiving the 250 Hinayana precepts, or gusokukai, in Todai-ji Temple, one of the Three Kaidan (Seats of Ordination).
sen.cmt: Changed word order and reworded translation'(23 years old)'→'when he was 23 years old'Added explanation of 'Kaidan'
sen.e: In 816, when he was 23 years old, he was ordained, receiving the 250 Hinayana precepts, or gusokukai, in Todai-ji Temple, one of the Three Kaidan (Seats of Ordination).

sen.j: この年、師最澄の東国巡遊に従って故郷下野を訪れる。
sen.e: He accompanied his master Saicho on Togoku junyu (pilgrimage to Kanto region) and visited his childhood home of Shimotsuke during this year.
During the same year, he accompanied his master, Saicho, on a pilgrimage to the Kanto region and visited his childhood home of Shimotsuke.
sen.cmt: during this year'→'During the same year' and moved to beginning.'Togoku junyu (pilgrimage to Kanto region)'→'a pilgrimage to the Kanto region'
sen.e: During the same year, he accompanied his master, Saicho, on a pilgrimage to the Kanto region and visited his childhood home of Shimotsuke Province.

sen.j: 最澄のこの旅行は新しく立てた天台宗の法華一乗の教えを全国に広める為、全国に6箇所を選んでそこに宝塔を建て一千部八千巻の法華経を置いて地方教化・国利安福の中心地としようとするものであった。
sen.e: The purpose of this trip for Saicho was to spread the words of newly established Tendai's Hokke ichijo and pick six locations in Japan to build the hoto as the center of local religious and national medical service following the One Thousand edition Eight Thousand Volume Lotus Sutra scriptures.
sen.cmt: 一千部八千巻→One Thousand edition Eight Thousand Volume と断しました[定訳不明]
sen.e: Saicho's reason for taking this trip was to spread the newly established Tendai sect's Hokke ichijo (Single Vehicle of the Lotus) teachings and to pick six locations throughout Japan to build hoto to serve as local religious and national medical service centres, following the One Thousand Edition Eight Thousand Volume Lotus Sutra sutra.
sen.cmt: Changed word orderAdded explanation of 'Hokke ichijo'.Not sure about 'One Thousand Edition Eight Thousand Volume'
sen.e: Saicho's reason for taking this trip was to spread the newly established Tendai Sect's Hokke ichijo (Single Vehicle of the Lotus) teachings and to pick six locations throughout Japan to build hoto to serve as local religious and national medical service centres, following the One Thousand Edition Eight Thousand Volume Lotus Sutra sutra.

sen.j: 817年（弘仁8年）3月6日、菩薩戒を教授師として諸弟子に授けるとともに自らも大乗戒を受ける。
sen.e: Once Ennin began to teach bosatsukai and gained pupils, he received daijokai himself on March 6, 817.
Once Ennin began to teach bosatsukai (bodhisattva precepts) and gain pupils, he received daijokai (Mahayana precepts) himself on March 6, 817.
Once Ennin began to teach bosatsukai (bodhisattva precepts) and gain pupils, he received daijokai (Mahayana precepts) himself on March 6, 817.

sen.j: 性は円満にして温雅、眉の太い人であったと言われる。
sen.e: He was said to be an amicable and graceful person with thick eyebrows.
He was said to be an amicable and graceful person with thick eyebrows.
He was said to be an amicable and graceful person with thick eyebrows.

sen.j: 浄土宗の開祖法然は、私淑する円仁の衣をまといながら亡くなったという。
sen.e: Honen of the founder of Jodo Sect supposedly died while wearing the clothes of Ennin whom he adored.
Honen, the founder of Jodo Sect, supposedly died while wearing the clothes of Ennin, whom he adored.
Honen, the founder of Jodo Sect (the Pure Land Sect), supposedly died while wearing the clothes of Ennin, whom he adored.

sen.j: 遣唐使の渡海の困難
sen.e: Difficult Sea Voyage of the Kentoshi (Japanese Delegates to China)
Difficult Sea Voyage of the Kentoshi (Japanese Delegates to China)
Difficult Sea Voyage of the Kentoshi (Japanese Delegates to China)

sen.j: 836年（承和 (日本)2年）、1回目の渡航失敗、翌837年（承和3年）、2回目の渡航を試みたが失敗した。
sen.e: He failed the first voyage in 836 and attempted the second in the following year of 837, but was unsuccessful.
His first voyage in 836 was a failure and a second attempted voyage the following year was also unsuccessful.
sen.cmt: Changed word order.Removed 'in 837'―の not really necessary.
sen.e: His first voyage in 836 was a failure and a second attempted voyage the following year was also unsuccessful.

sen.j: 838年（承和5年）6月13日、博多津を出港。
sen.e: He left Hakatanotsu on June 13, 838.
He left Hakatanotsu on June 13, 838.
He left Hakatanotsu on June 13, 838.

sen.j: 『入唐求法巡礼行記』をこの日から記し始める。

On this day, he started to write "Nitto Guho Junrei Koki" (The Record of a Pilgrimage to China in Search of the Law).

sen.j: 志賀島から揚州東梁豊村まで8日間で無事渡海する（しかし「四つの船」のうち1艘は遭難している）。
sen.e: He safely travelled from Shikanoshima Island to Dong Liang Village of Yangzhou for 8 days (However, one among 'four ships' sunk).

sen.e: He travelled from Shikanoshima Island to Dong Liang Village in Yangzhou, arriving safely after 8 days sailing, although one of the 'four ships' sank).
He travelled from Shikanoshima Island to Dong Liang Village in Yangzhou, arriving safely after eight days sailing, although one of the 'four ships' sank).

sen.j: 円仁の乗った船は助かったものの、船のコントロールが利かず渚に乗り上げてしまい、円仁はずぶ濡れ、船は全壊するという形での上陸だった（『行記』838年（開成4年）7月2日条）。
sen.e: Although Ennin's vessel was fine, they lost the control of the ship to beach on the shore, Ennin became completely soaked, and the ship was completely destroyed ("Kouki (The Record of a Pilgrimage to China in Search of the Law)," dated July 2, 838).

Although Ennin's vessel was fine, during disembarkation they lost the control of the ship and ran aground, leaving Ennin soaked through and the ship completely destroyed (from "Kouki (The Record of a Pilgrimage to China in Search of the Law)," July 2, 838 entry).
sen.cmt: to beach on the shore'→'during disembarkation…ran aground''completely' was repeated so changed 1st one to 'soaked through'

sen.cmt: Kouki→Kokiに修正、クォーテーション内のカッコ文の位置を移動

sen.j: ※上陸日である唐の開成4年7月2日は日本の承和5年7月2日と日付が一致していた。
sen.e: * The day of the landing, July 2nd of the 4th year of Kaisei for Tang Dynasty was same as Japan's July 2nd of the 5th year of Jowa.
* The day of the landing, July 2nd of the 4th year of Kaisei for the Tang Dynasty was same as Japan's July 2nd of the 5th year of Jowa.
* The day of the landing, July 2nd of the 4th year of Kaicheng era for the Tang Dynasty was same as Japan's July 2nd of the 5th year of Jowa era.
sen.cmt: Kaiseiは開成の日本語読みのため、Kaichengとし、eraをつけました。(参照:http://ci.nii.ac.jp/naid/110000449107/en) Jowa→Jowa eraとしました。

sen.j: 唐と日本で同じ暦を使っているのだから当然ではあるが、異国でも日付が全く同じであることに改めて感動している（『行記』838年（開成4年）7月2日条）。
sen.e: It was natural since both Japan and the Tang dynasty used the same calendar, but Ennin was moved by the fact that date was same even on a foreign soil ("Kouki," dated July 2, 838).
This was not surprising since both Japan and the Tang Dynasty used the same calendar, but Ennin was moved by the fact that the date was the same even on foreign soil ("Kouki," July 2, 838 entry).
sen.cmt: It was natural'→'This was not surprising'Capitalized 'd' of 'dynasty'Added 'the' before 'date', 'same'.Erased 'a'
sen.e: This was not surprising since both Japan and the Tang Dynasty used the same calendar, but Ennin was moved by the fact that the date was the same even on foreign soil ("Koki," July 2, 838 entry).

sen.j: 天台山を目指すが…
sen.e: Attempted to head to Mount Tiantai but…
Attempt to reach Mount Tiantai
Attempt to reach Mt. Tiantai

sen.j: 最後の遣唐使として唐に留学するが、もともと請益僧（短期の入唐僧）であったため目指す天台山へは旅行許可が下りず（短期の入唐僧の為日程的に無理と判断されたか）、空しく帰国せねばならない事態に陥った。
sen.e: He went to study abroad as the last of kentoshi but since he was shoyakuso (a monk who stayed in Tang for a short period), he was not given a travel permit (perhaps it was considered impossible due to him being shoyakuso with a limited schedule) to Mount Tiantai, and he had to go back to Japan without a choice.

He was the last of kentoshi to study in China but, since he was shoyakuso (a monk who stayed in Tang for a short period), he was not given a travel permit to Mount Tiantai (perhaps because it was considered impossible due to his limited schedule) and he had no choice but to go back to Japan.
sen.cmt: Changed word order'without a choice'→'no choice''to him being shoyakuso with a'→'his'
sen.e: He was the last of kentoshi to study in China but, since he was shoyakuso (a monk who stayed in Tang for a short period), he was not given a travel permit to Mt. Tiantai (perhaps because it was considered impossible due to his limited schedule) and he had no choice but to go back to Japan.

sen.j: 唐への留住を唐皇帝に何度も願い出るが認められない。
sen.e: He asked for the permission to reside at Tang many times to the Tang emperor but was not granted.
He asked the Tang emperor for the permission to reside at Tang many times but was always refused.
He asked the Tang emperor for the permission to reside at Tang many times but was always refused.

sen.j: そこで円仁は遣唐使一行と離れて危険をおかして不法在唐を決意する（外国人僧の滞在には唐皇帝の勅許が必要）。
sen.e: As a result, he decides to do the dangerous job of leaving the group of kentoshi to illegally reside in Tang (Foreign monks were required to have the permit from Tang emperor).
As a result, he decided on the dangerous course of leaving the group of kentoshi to illegally reside in China (Foreign monks were required to have a permit from the Tang emperor).
As a result, he decided on the dangerous course of leaving the group of kentoshi to illegally reside in China (Foreign monks were required to have a permit from the Tang emperor).

sen.j: 天台山に居た最澄の姿を童子（子供）の時に見ていたという若い天台僧敬文が、天台山からはるばる円仁を訪ねてきた。
sen.e: The young Mount Tiantai monk, Keibun, who witnessed Saicho staying at Mount Tiantai when he was a child, came all the way from Mount Tiantai to visit Ennin.

The young Tiantai monk, Keibun (敬文), who as a child had seen Saicho staying at Mt. Tiantai, came all the way from Mt. Tiantai to visit Ennin.
sen.cmt: 読みが不明のため、"Keibun (敬文)"とし、The young Mount Tiantai monk→The young Tiantai monkとしました。天台山→Mt. Tiantaiとしました。

sen.j: 日本から高僧が揚州に来ているという情報を得て、懐かしく思って訪れて来たのだという。
sen.e: He stated that he came to visit since he felt longing after hearing a word that the high monk from Japan was visiting Yangzhou
He stated that he had come to visit because hearing a high monk from Japan was visiting Yangzhou had rekindled some fond memories.
sen.cmt: Changed translation slightly― 'felt longing'→'rekindled some fond memories'
sen.e: He stated that he had come to visit because hearing a high monk from Japan was visiting Yangzhou had rekindled some fond memories.

sen.j: 唐滞在中の円仁の世話を何かと見てくれるようになる。

He took care of Ennin during his stay in China.
sen.cmt: staying at Tang'→'during his stay in China'

sen.j: 海州東海県で遣唐大使一行から離れ、一夜を過ごすも村人達に不審な僧だと警戒され（中国語通じず、「自分は新羅僧だ」と主張しているが新羅の言葉でもない様だ、怪しい僧だ）、役所に突き出されてしまう。
sen.e: He left kentoshi group at Donghai of Haeju, but villagers considered him as a questionable monk (He was suspicious since he could not understand Chinese and although he claimed that 'I'm the Silla monk,' he did not seem to speak Silla) and was handed over to the government office after spending one night at the village.

He left the kentoshi group at Donghai in Haeju, but villagers considered him suspicious (he could not understand Chinese and although he claimed that 'I'm a Sillan monk,' he did not seem to speak Korean) and handed over to the government office after one night the village.

sen.e: He left the kentoshi group at Donghai in Haeju, but villagers considered him suspicious (he could not understand Chinese and although he claimed that 'I'm a Sillan monk,' he did not seem to speak Korean) and handed over to the government office after one night the village.

sen.j: 再び遣唐大使一行のところに連れ戻されてしまった（『行記』839年（開成4年）4月10日条）。

He was taken back to the kentoshi group ("Kouki," April 10, 839 entry).

sen.e: Back then, Silla sea merchants including Jang Bogo prospered in the neighborhoods of Shandong Peninsula of China, but he received the help from Tang residing Silla society in Chishanji and succeeded to stay at Tang (although he remained as a illegal resident, he was able to obtain a travel permit).
sen.cmt: 赤山→斥山→Chisanjiと判断しました。 [http://www.silkroads.ch/115501/115522.html][http://21coe.kokugakuin.ac.jp/modules/wfsection/article.php?articleid=34], 浦→中国語の為、読めませんでした[定訳不明]
sen.e: Back then, Silla sea merchants, including Jang Bogo, prospered in the neighborhoods of the Shandong Peninsula of China and, with the help of Sillans residing in Chishanji, he was able to stay in China (although he remained as an illegal resident, he was able to obtain a travel permit).

Back then, Silla sea merchants, including Bogo JANG, prospered in the neighborhoods of the Shandong Peninsula of China and, with the help of Sillans residing in Chishanji, he was able to stay in China (although he remained as an illegal resident, he was able to obtain a travel permit).
sen.cmt: 人名のため、Jang Bogo→Bogo JANGとしました。

sen.j: 日本政府は円仁を無事連れ帰ってきた金珍ら新羅商人に十分に報酬を報いる様に太政官符を発し、ここで9年6ヶ月に及んだ日記『入唐求法巡礼行記』の筆を擱いている（『行記』847年（承和14年）12月14日条。54歳）
sen.e: The Japanese government gave out daijokanpu to award Kim Jin and Silla merchants who safely brought back Ennin, and the diary, "Nitto guho junreiki" that lasted for nine years and six months ended that day ("Kouki," dated December 14, 847, 54 years old.).

The Japanese government gave out daijokanpu to award Kim Jin and the Sillan merchants who had safely brought back Ennin, and the diary, "Nitto Guho Junreiki" that had lasted for nine years and six months ended that day ("Kouki," December 14, 847 entry, Aged 54).

The Japanese government gave out daijokanpu (official documents issued by Daijokan, Grand Council of State) to award Jin KIM and the Sillan merchants who had safely brought back Ennin, and the diary, "Nitto Guho Junrei Koki" that had lasted for nine years and six months ended that day ("Koki," December 14, 847 entry, Aged 54).
sen.cmt: 「太政官符」の補足を追加、Kim Jin→Jin KIM、Junreiki→Junrei Koki、Kouki→Kokiに修正

sen.j: この9年6ヶ月に及ぶ求法の旅の間、書き綴った日記が『入唐求法巡礼行記』で、これは日本人による最初の本格的旅行記であり、時の皇帝、武宗 (唐)による仏教弾圧である会昌の廃仏の様子を生々しく伝えるものとして歴史資料としても高く評価されている。
sen.e: This diary written down for nine years and half trip to seek Buddhism was "Nitto guho Junreiki," and is the first genuine Japanese Travel Records and highly regarded as the historical document that vividly depicted the Great Anti-Buddhist Persecution's anti-Buddhist activities of Emperor Wuzong (Tang) at that time.

The diary written during Ennin's nine-and-a-half-year journey to seek Buddhism, "Nitto guho Junreiki," is the first genuine Japanese travelogue and is highly valued as an historical document that vividly depicts the anti-Buddhist activities of the Tang Emperor, Wuzong, during the Great Anti-Buddhist Persecution.
sen.cmt: This'→'the''down for'→'during Ennin's''nine years and half trip'→'nine-and-a-half-year journey' Deleted 'and''Travel Records'→'travelogue'Changed word order at end of sentence
sen.e: The diary written during Ennin's nine-and-a-half-year journey to seek Buddhism, "Nitto Guho Junrei Koki," is the first genuine Japanese travelogue and is highly valued as an historical document that vividly depicts the anti-Buddhist activities of the Tang Emperor, Wuzong, during the Great Anti-Buddhist Persecution.
sen.cmt: Junreiki→Junrei Kokiに修正、および各単語の頭文字を大文字にし"Nitto Guho Junrei Koki"としました。

sen.j: 巡礼行記によると円仁は一日約40kmを徒歩で移動していたという。
sen.e: According to Junreiki ("Nitto guho Junreiki"), Ennin travelled around 40 km on foot.
According to his diary, he travelled around 40 km a day on foot.
sen.cmt: Junreiki ("Nitto guho Junreiki")'→'his diary''Ennin'→'he'added 'a day' as in original
sen.e: According to his diary, he travelled around 40 km a day on foot.

sen.j: 目黒不動として知られる瀧泉寺や山形市にある立石寺、松島の瑞巌寺を開いたと言われる。
sen.e: He supposedly established Ryusen-ji Temple known for Meguro Fudo, Risshaku-ji Temple in Yamagata City, and Zuigan-ji Temple of Matsushima.
He supposedly established Ryusen-ji Temple, also known as Meguro Fudo, Risshaku-ji Temple in Yamagata City, and Zuigan-ji Temple in Matsushima.
He supposedly established Ryusen-ji Temple, also known as Meguro Fudo, Risshaku-ji Temple in Yamagata City, and Zuigan-ji Temple in Matsushima.

sen.j: 慈覚大師円仁が開山したり再興したりしたと伝わる寺は関東に209寺、東北に331寺余（）である。
sen.e: There are 209 temples in Kanto and around 331 temples in Tohoku that were supposedly established (by clearing a mountain and building temples) or restored by Jikaku Daishi Ennin.
There are 209 temples in Kanto and around 331 temples in Tohoku that were supposedly established or restored by Jikaku Daishi Ennin.
sen.cmt: Removed section in brackets - original has '開山' but don’t feel it adds anything
sen.e: There are 209 temples in Kanto region and around 331 temples in Tohoku region that were supposedly established or restored by Jikaku Daishi Ennin.
sen.cmt: Kanto region, Tohoku regionとしました。

sen.j: 後に、円仁派を、円珍派（寺門派）に対し山門派と呼ぶ。
sen.e: Eventually, Ennin-ha (the way of Ennin) was called as Sanmon-ha in comparison to Enchin-ha (Jimon-ha).
Eventually, Ennin-ha (the way of Ennin) became known as Sanmon-ha to distinguish it from Enchin-ha (Jimon-ha).

sen.e: Eventually, Ennin school became known as Sanmon school to distinguish it from Enchin school (Jimon school).
